classes.title: GENZ MEDIA
classes.description: GenZ is the first generation to grow up with and to be active users and pro ducers of social media. ?GenZ Media? explores representations of and commen tary about social media. In keeping with a distinguishing characteristic of social media, the class includes interactive media components. GenZ is gen erally defined as people born between the late 1990s and early 2010s.

classes.title: MEDIA CRITICISM
classes.description: Develop the analytical tools required for a critical   understanding of the interrelationship between media, culture,   and society in America. Special attention given to how social   structures shape media and how media products in return affect   our cultural practices and patterns.

classes.title: INTERNSHIP
classes.description: An opportunity for training, career sampling, and contacts in the film or television industry. Required are approximately 100 hours of work per quar ter, a   final five-page report, and a supervisor's letter of verification.

classes.title: INDEPENDENT STUDIES
classes.description: Selected research under the direction of a faculty member.

classes.title: HIST NEW WAVES FILM
classes.description: International film history since 1959. Historical accounts of   film as an aesthetic form, a social force, an economic   institution, and a technology is considered.

classes.title: NEW WAVE HONORS
classes.description: Students receive one unit for the honors seminar. Intended for   highly mot ivated Letters and Science Honors Students.

classes.title: TELEGRAPHY  AND TV
classes.description: International history of electronic media and broadcasting   from telegraphy to early television. Historical accounts of   telegraphy, radio, and early television as cultural forms,   communications technologies, and social political and   economic institutions are considered.

classes.title: PRODUCTION TECH
classes.description: An introduction to video production and technology, focusing on the fundame ntal concepts of the ?moving image? including core aspects of shooting, lig hting, sound-recording & editing. Lectures complement the hands-on labs by covering key concepts, dissecting various productions, and learning the wor kflow from pre to post-production.

classes.title: CREW PRODUCTION
classes.description: Instruction in the basic techniques of 16mm filmmaking via the   production of crew projects over two consecutive quarters.   Post-production through composite print.

classes.title: ANIMATION INTRO
classes.description: A look at the techniques and history of animation with   emphasis on the major styles and methods of production,   including cel, direct, photo, three-dimensional and computer.   Close examination of significant films combined with   production of a class project.

classes.title: PILOT WRITING
classes.description: Workshop approach to writing a half-hour sitcom pilot.

classes.title: SOUND PRODUCTION
classes.description: A workshop approach to explorations of sound recording,   editing, and mixi ng in project production.

classes.title: MAGIC LANTERN
classes.description: Students learn the ins and outs of organizing and executing a   film series , using the IV Theater as a "lab." They gain hands-  on experience programm ing, tracking down prints, contacting   and working with distributors and f ilmmakers, fundraising,   advertising, engaging in audience outreach, theat er managing,   exhibiting, researching, and reviewing.

classes.title: ADAPTATION
classes.description: This film criticism course examines the adaptation of literary works for bo th film and television. Considering plays, novels, children?s literature, a nd graphic novels and their screen adaptations, we explore key scholarly qu estions about adaptation theory, such as fidelity to source text. Works stu died may include: William Shakespeare?s Hamlet (including Haider), Jane Aus ten?s Emma, Arthur Conan Doyle?s Sherlock Holmes series, Shirley Jackson?s The Haunting of Hill House, J.K. Rowling?s Harry Potter series, and Black P anther.

classes.title: TV NARRATIVE FORM
classes.description: Introduces students to the "close reading / watching" method of studying pr estige television form and style. In recent years, television studies has s hifted to focus on close reading / watching as a key method for analyzing p restige television drama. Critics like Ramona Wray and Jason Mittell have e xtended David Bordwell's historical poetics and applied it to television's narrative form and style at both the local episodic and series levels.

classes.title: ENVIRONMENTAL FILM
classes.description: Presents popular films, professional documentaries   representing  trends, images, and issues associated with   natural and human environments. Visual images and critical   thinking skills are combined to enhance understanding of media   presentation of environmental issues. May be linked to short   creative projects.

classes.title: ARCHIVING
classes.description: A seminar/workshop examining film archiving with particular emphasis on the silent era and the ongoing investigation into what still exists, where it exists, how it is managed, preserved and restored.

classes.title: TOPICS IN ANALYSIS
classes.description: A seminar for advanced students examining in-depth a   particular problem or issue in the analysis of film and its   consequences for history, theory, or aesthetics of film,   television and digital media.

classes.title: NAZI PROPAGANDA FIL
classes.description: Explores Nazi film's role as an instrument for cultural diplomacy and propa ganda in its historical and global political contexts. Topics include Germa n-Japanese co-productions, German-American moviegoing, Nazi films in South America, worldwide competition with Allied films, and the films' contempora ry legacy.

classes.title: TOPICS IN ANALYSIS
classes.description: A seminar for advanced students examining in-depth a   particular problem or issue in the analysis of film and its   consequences for history, theory, or aesthetics of film,   television and digital media.

classes.title: SHORT FORMAT
classes.description: Seminar surveys several fascinating issues regarding the history, productio n, distribution, and exhibition of short films. We examine the distinctive story and aesthetic/formal strategies used in many of the landmark short fi lms and filmmakers from throughout cinema history. The emphasis is on more recent shorts. We explore the recent explosion of attention to shorts and t he expanded opportunities available to filmmakers to get their shorts seen at film festivals, on cable, and perhaps most significantly, on the Interne t.

classes.title: THEME PARK AS MEDIA
classes.description: Introduces site-based research methods by exploring theme parks and attract ions from a range of media studies perspectives. Students design projects t hat consider space and material alongside existing analytical frameworks, s ituating themed entertainment within the contemporary media landscape.

classes.title: ADVAN SCREENWRITING
classes.description: A course intended for students who have successfully completed   Film Studies188A and have a full-length screenplay in process   which they want to complete.

classes.title: T.V. WRITING
classes.description: Introduction to fundamentals of writing for television   including: the situation comedy, the hour-long drama, the MOW,   the miniseries, and children's programming. Investigation of   the practical and creative tools necessary for programming.   Investigation of the practical and creative tools necessary   for navigating successful television scripts.

classes.title: DISABILITY AND MEDI
classes.description: This course introduces students to the central models within Disability Stu dies and their application to the field of Film and Media Studies, focusing especially on issues of representation, disability stardom, as well as med ia access.

classes.title: GLOBAL NEWS MEDIA
classes.description: Fake news, the "corporate media," alternative facts. This class explores co ntemporary conversations about crises in news media forms by examining the histories, technologies, industries, policies, and cultural norms that shap e global and local news cultures, specifically focusing on moving-image new s and investigative content.

classes.title: POPULAR MUSIC AND
classes.description: Explores the social history and cultural politics of popular music and yout h culture, with an emphasis on the relations between musical meaning, techn ological mediation, cultural value, and social power.

classes.title: INTERNSHIP
classes.description: An opportunity for training, career sampling, and contacts in   the film or television industry. Required are approximately   100 hours of work a quarter, a final five-page report, and a   supervisor's letter of verification.

classes.title: POLLOCK INTERNSHIP
classes.description: Students gain professional skills, including writing event   proposals, marketing, and theater operations. Over three quarters, this class emphasizes different aspects of broadcast production, which include Q&As/talk shows, sitcoms, and directing. May be taken up to three times.

classes.title: SENIOR HONORS SEM
classes.description: A one-quarter directed study, to be conducted as outlined in   the description of the Senior Honors Program. Honors   candidates will write a senior thesis on a topic approved by   film studies faculty.

classes.title: INDEPENDENT STUDIES
classes.description: Selected research under the direction of a faculty member.

classes.title: INDEP RESEARCH ASST
classes.description: Course work shall consist of faculty supervised research   assistance.
